item.title: Shell into Kubernetes Pod
item.description: Syntax: kubectl exec --stdin --tty <pod_name> -- /bin/bash Example, with the following pods me@example:~$ kubectl get pod NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE cert-manager-cainjector-68c88cc858-c2rhx 1/1 Running 0 109m cert-manager-d76d644df-pgqn9 1/1 Running 0 109m cert-manager-webhook-6dd68c6fbc-rzcln 1/1 Running 0 109m my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 1/1 Running 0 108m my-first-vanilla-drupal-mariadb-0 1/1 Running 0 108m traffic-cop-nginx-ingress-controller-5d685cfd59-pjfdg 1/1 Running 0 144m traffic-cop-nginx-ingress-default-backend-55f6bcb48-brg6b 1/1 Running 0 144m Run this to go to the drupal pod my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 kubectl exec --stdin --tty my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 -- /bin/bash It’s just like any docker container or linux machine when you’re in:
